articles.title: Seal deaths raise fears about nasty strain of bird flu
articles.summary: Heard Island is a sub-Antarctic island 4000 km southwest of Perth. There are signs of H5 bird flu on the island, but it's not confirmed. Australia is the only continent in the world free of the H5 strain of bird flu, which has spread across most parts of the globe, including sections of Antarctica.

articles.title: Seal deaths raise fears about nasty strain of bird flu
articles.author: Ethan James
articles.summary: Heard Island, about 4000 km southwest of Perth, has signs of H5 avian influenza for the first time. The virus has been found on the French Kerguelen and Crozet sub-Antarctic islands less than 450 km from Heard Island. Australia is the only continent in the world free of the H5 strain of bird flu, which has spread across most parts of the globe.

articles.title: Experts issue worrisome predictions about upcoming US ski season: 'It is quite possible'
articles.author: Catherine Wilkins
articles.summary: Experts issue worrisome predictions about upcoming US ski season: 'It is quite possible' Skiers headed to Colorado this winter may need to postpone their trips as meteorologists predict less-than-ideal skiing conditions. Warming temperatures in the Pacific are influencing climate patterns. La Ni√±a typically leads to warmer and drier conditions in the South and cooler and wetter conditions in North.

articles.title: Rising Sea Levels: Millions of Buildings at Risk üåä
articles.summary: Sea level rise is a consequence of climate change. 840 million buildings in the Global South are at risk of inundation due to sea level rise. Even a modest 0.5-meter rise could inundate roughly 3 million buildings. Even partial disruptions could trigger cascading effects throughout the global economy. Coastal communities and governments need to plan for the inevitable.

articles.title: Heavy rains and flooding from Tropical Storm Melissa in Jamaica and the Dominican Republic
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Melissa is bringing heavy rains and flooding to Jamaica and the Dominican Republic. Hundreds of thousands of people are without drinking water. The National Hurricane Center of the United States warned Melissa could become a major hurricane over the weekend. The World Food Programme is analyzing meteorological data to guide actions aimed at protecting vulnerable communities.

articles.title: Millions of Buildings Threatened by Rising Seas This Century, Study Warns
articles.author: Russell Mclendon
articles.summary: Rising seas threaten millions of lives and livelihoods in coastal regions, along with untold swaths of vital infrastructure. About a tenth of humanity live within 5 km of the shoreline. The study covered 840 million buildings across the Global South and used satellite data and detailed elevation maps.

articles.title: Melissa threatens Cuba and the country trembles: Empty warehouses, patched roofs, and fear in every home
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Melissa is a tropical storm in the central Caribbean with 75 km/h winds. It could become a hurricane on Saturday and reach greater intensity on Sunday. There is a risk of heavy rainfall and landslides in eastern Cuba. Yasser Sosa Tamayo, a writer and activist from Santiago, wrote a text on Facebook about the country's vulnerability in the face of the storm.

articles.title: Australia on Alert: Potential H5 Bird Flu in Southern Ocean
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Signs consistent with H5 bird flu have been observed on Heard Island, located in the Southern Ocean. The observations align with global outbreaks of H5 virus, which has impacted wild birds, poultry, and dairy cows across multiple continents. The virus has already reached nearby Indonesia in 2022 and Antarctica in 2023.

articles.title: Australia says H5 bird flu suspected in sub-Antarctic island
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: There have been unusual levels of elephant seal deaths on Heard Island in the Southern Ocean. The H5 bird flu has spread widely in wild birds worldwide and is causing outbreaks in poultry and U.S. dairy cows. Australia remains the only continent free of the highly contagious viral flu.

articles.title: Australia says H5 bird flu suspected in sub-Antarctic island
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: Scientists have seen symptoms consistent with the destructive H5 bird flu strain on Heard Island in the Southern Ocean. There have been unusual levels of deaths of elephant seals on the island. It is not confirmed but it is not unexpected, the Agriculture department said in a statement.

articles.title: South Korea's fishermen keep dying. Is climate change to blame?
articles.author: Jean Mackenzie
articles.summary: Last year, 164 people were killed or went missing in accidents in the seas around South Korea. Most were fishermen whose boats sunk or capsized. The government launched an investigation into the accidents. The head of the taskforce pinpointed climate change as one of the major causes. The number of marine weather warnings around the Korean Peninsula has increased by 65%.

articles.title: US weather disasters through June have caused at least $101 billion in damages
articles.author: Julia Musto
articles.summary: 14 separate events each caused over $1 billion in damages and 174 fatalities in the first half of 2025. Southern California wildfires were the most expensive disaster, costing $60 billion and marking the costliest wildfire event ever recorded. The increasing frequency of such events is attributed by scientists to the climate crisis and rising carbon emissions.

articles.title: Researchers warn of the urgent need to include the cumulative effects of extreme climate events ...
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: A new analysis warns that penguin survival hinges on a shift in how science and conservation policy approach climate change, rather than examining it as a result of current policies.   ¬†   .   "Penguin survival depends on how scientists and conservationists treat climate change."

articles.title: Iceland Records First Mosquitoes Amid Rapid Arctic Warming
articles.author: Greek Reporter
articles.summary: Iceland has officially recorded the insects within its borders for the first time. Researchers link the change to the Arctic's rapidly warming climate. AfroBrazilian saw a strange fly on a red wine ribbon on October 16th. He reports it was a Culiseta annulata.

articles.title: Deadly H5 strain of bird flu suspected on sub-Antarctic Heard Island in the Southern Ocean
articles.author: Jano Gibson
articles.summary: Scientists fear the deadly H5 strain of bird flu has reached one of Australia's sub-Antarctic islands after signs of the disease were seen in elephant seals on Heard Island. Wildlife experts travelled to the volcanic island in the Southern Ocean on the icebreaker RSV Nuyina. The suspected arrival of the virus cannot be confirmed until the ship returns with samples for testing.

articles.title: As Haiti, Jamaica, Cuba brace for tropical storm, World Food Program preps response
articles.author: Jacqueline Charles
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Melissa is expected to strengthen into a hurricane as soon as Saturday. U.N. World Food Program staff are helping authorities in Haiti and Cuba and have pre-positioned pallets at a regional hub in Barbados. The food agency is also in touch with the government of Jamaica.

articles.title: Hampshire flood programme protects almost 200 homes
articles.author: Sophie Day
articles.summary: Almost 200 households in Hampshire and Isle of Wight are now better protected thanks to a flood protection programme. Environment Agency's initiative has implemented safety measures at more than 120 properties and work is ongoing to protect an additional 70 homes. The announcement coincides with Flood Action Week, the annual campaign urging people to check their flood risk and prepare for potential flooding.

articles.title: Lagos Climate Summit To Unlock Funding For Africa's Ocean Sustainability
articles.author: Ayobamiji Komolafe
articles.summary: The 2025 International Climate Change Summit will take place from November 6-7, 2025 in Lagos. The theme is 'Blue Economy, Green Money: Financing Africa's Coastal Resilience and Ocean Innovation'. It will focus on four thematic areas: the blue economy, green finance, innovation and youth empowerment, and partnerships. It is expected to attract over 1,200 delegates, including global chief executives, financiers, researchers and young innovators.

articles.title: Deadliest Catch: Can Crabbing Survive Warming Seas?
articles.author: Dr. Priya Deshmukh
articles.summary: 90% of the Bering Sea's snow crab population has disappeared in a few years due to climate change. Alaska had to cancel its lucrative crab fishing season for the first time in history. The collapse is a warning of how marine ecosystems are buckling under the strain of climate change and a test case for predicting the future of commercially vital species.

articles.title: Tiny Island Nation Of Tuvalu Has A Plan In Place To Migrate Its Entire Population Due To Rising Sea Levels
articles.author: Michael Levanduski
articles.summary: The leaders of Tuvalu signed an agreement with Australia to plan for the migration of citizens from the island nation. They want to provide 280 residents per year with a permanent climate visa, allowing them to move to Australia. They are also working to 3D scan their islands to preserve their cultural heritage in the event the island is lost to the rising waters.

articles.title: As Haiti, Jamaica, Cuba brace for tropical storm, World Food Program preps response
articles.author: Jacqueline Charles
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Melissa is moving towards Jamaica and southwest Haiti. The U.N. World Food Program is helping authorities in Haiti and Cuba prepare for the storm. The Dominican Republic has already placed nine provinces under red alert. Haiti is under a vigilance warning, including the region that encompasses Port-au-Prince, where armed groups control much of the capital.

articles.title: Exploring Global Land Temperature Variability with ERA5-Land
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Recent research has unveiled intricate spatio-temporal modes of global land surface air temperature variability, using advanced analyses from the ERA5-Land dataset. The study's significance rests in its thorough examination of the data, which offers high-resolution atmospheric reanalysis. The integration of advanced modeling tools allowed for a more granular exploration, shedding light on temperature trends that can have profound implications for ecological systems and agriculture.

articles.title: Doable climate solutions needed
articles.author: editorial
articles.summary: Finance Minister Muhammad Aurangzeb has rightly identified climate change as an "existential" threat to Pakistan's economic ambitions. Pakistan's population contributes less than 1% to global greenhouse gas emissions, but its own investment in climate change adaptation is arguably not even at the 1%. Pakistan's power sector remains unreliable and unaffordable, with households spending about 17% of their income on electricity - among the highest in the region. Domestic financing must be prioritised.

articles.title: Lagos recommits to converting its coastal challenges to economic, ecological advantage
articles.author: Adenle Ahmed Abiola
articles.summary: The Lagos State Government is hosting the 11th International Climate Change Summit. The state government is investing in flood mitigation, renewable energy, and circular economy models that can serve as templates for other cities across the continent. The 2025 edition will host more than 1,200 delegates including international agency heads, global CEOs, financiers and youth innovators.

articles.title: Miscarriages, preterm births: Extreme heat risks US pregnant farmworkers; immigration fears silence them
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Pregnant agricultural workers in the U.S. are increasingly at risk as climate change drives higher temperatures. Low-income Latino immigrants are among the hardest hit. Some days it feels like the sun is burning them alive, but they have to fight for their children.

articles.title: Record-breaking heat set for Queensland while freezing blasts and snow land in the south as mix of extremes sweep across the country
articles.author: Conor Breslin
articles.summary: Australia is heading into a weekend of extreme and unpredictable weather. There is a heatwave warning in force across parts of northern Queensland and the Northern Territory. A cold front sweeping through Victoria and Tasmania will drag temperatures well below average, with more late-season snow possible over higher ground.

articles.title: Millions of red crabs begin migration across Christmas Island
articles.author: Rod McGuirk
articles.summary: Tens of millions of red crabs have begun their annual migration across Christmas Island, an Australian territory in the Indian Ocean. The island's 1,200 human residents actively assist the crustaceans, using leaf blowers and garden rakes to clear them from roads and driveways. Female crabs are expected to release their spawn into the ocean on November 14 or 15.

articles.title: Liberia: Epa, UN Women Begin Validation W/Shop for Liberia's Climate Change Gap
articles.summary: The two-day validation workshop for Liberia's Climate Change Gender Action Plan is taking place at MUSU's Spot in Congo Town. The workshop aims to review and validate the revised Gender and Climate Change Action Plan (GCCAP). It also aims to address the current realities facing vulnerable groups, especially women, children and persons with disabilities.

articles.title: NHRC urges 19 states, 4 UTs to take preventive measures to protect homeless during winter
articles.summary: The National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) has urged 19 state governments and four UT Administrations to take preemptive steps and implement relief measures to protect vulnerable segments. The Commission acknowledges that changing weather patterns due to climate change affect human rights. Between 2019 and 2023, 3,639 people died from exposure to cold waves in India.

articles.title: NHRC Urges States to Tackle Cold Wave Threat to Vulnerable Populations
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) has issued a call to action, urging various Indian states and Union Territories to adopt 'pre-emptive steps' that will safeguard vulnerable groups from the upcoming cold wave. The NHRC has appealed to 19 state governments and four Union Territory administrations to implement immediate relief efforts.

articles.title: Ted Nordhaus's Epiphany
articles.author: Charles Rotter
articles.summary: Ted Nordhaus co-founded the Breakthrough Institute, which promotes climate change alarmism. Nordhaus admits that his worldview was built on 'apocalyptic models sprung from faulty assumptions'. The world is enjoying the safest and most technologically protected era in recorded history. The data 'overwhelm the climate signal', because what determines the cost of disasters is how rich, prepared, and well-built societies are.

articles.title: Bureau of Meteorology's site revamp bombs out
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: Bureau of Meteorology's website is useless. Children should be taught how to use and understand social media at a young age. Fossil fuels accounted for almost 29% of Australia's $193 billion in exports in 2023. China, Japan, and South Korea are transitioning to renewables and nuclear. Australia's prosperity will not rely on the use of fossil fuels.

articles.title: Flood programme helps almost 200 homes in Hampshire and IOW
articles.author: Sophie Day
articles.summary: Environment Agency's Property Flood Resilience initiative has helped almost 200 homes across Hampshire and the Isle of Wight. The initiative has implemented safety measures at more than 120 properties and work is ongoing to protect an additional 70 homes. The Met Office has warned of a wetter-than-average autumn.

articles.title: Expensive Challenges Follow As Our Sea Levels Rise
articles.author: Newport This Week Staff
articles.summary: Panelists appeared at 'Ports on the Frontline: Protecting R.I.'s Economy from Rising Seas' at an event sponsored by the Greater Newport County Chamber of Commerce. The experts ran off a list of problems faced by coastal communities and said solutions require long-term planning and deep searches for funding.

articles.title: Caspian Sea Water Levels Drop to Record Lows Amid Natural Climate Shifts
articles.author: Pravda
articles.summary: The shrinking of the Caspian Sea has become one of the most concerning environmental developments in recent years. Ecologists warn that consequences are inevitable, but say there is no point in trying to prevent them. The receding zone will reshape itself and many living organisms will face a crisis.

articles.title: Chinese FM spokesperson slams US think tank reports for 'distorting facts' in smear campaign over China-West Africa cooperation
articles.author: Global Times
articles.summary: Atlantic Council has accused China of causing environmental degradation through its mining, forestry, and fishing activities in West Africa. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Guo Jiakun said China has followed the principle of sincerity, real results, amity and good faith in promoting cooperation with Africa. Guo said some US think tanks distort facts and take information out of context in a deliberate attempt to smear and attack normal cooperation between China and West African countries.

articles.summary: Adapting to changes in the global weather and the global market is a challenge for Kopke's business. Kopke has to adapt to the changing global climate and the changing market as well as the changing economy.   √Ç  ¬†   in

articles.title: Himalayan Glacial lakes grow by 9.24% in 14 years: CWC report
articles.author: Ne Now News
articles.summary: Glacial lakes and water bodies in the Himalayan region have grown by 9.24% over the past 14 years, according to a new report by the Central Water Commission. The report highlights the visible impacts of climate change on the region. The total area of these water bodies increased from 5.30 lakh hectares in 2011 to 5.79 lakhs in 2025. 428 glacial lakes in India have expanded, prompting authorities to call for enhanced monitoring to prepare for potential disasters.

articles.title: Australia Red Crabs

articles.title: Not a Con Job
articles.author: Danish Bhutto
articles.summary: Pakistan's climate crisis is not an accident, it's the arithmetic of injustice. The 2010 floods affected nearly 20 million Pakistanis, destroyed roughly 1.6 million homes, destroyed about 2.2 million hectares of crops and caused 2000 deaths. The 2022 deluge affected 33 million people, some 8 million displaced, 1700 fatalities, and combined damages and economic losses of about $30 billion. President Donald Trump dismissed climate change as 'the greatest con job ever perpetrated on the world' during a high-profile address to the United Nations.

articles.title: Farming in the fire: Climate change threatens PH breadbasket
articles.author: Ludwig Federigan
articles.summary: The effects of climate change will be increasingly palpable across the Philippine agricultural landscape due to rising temperatures, erratic rainfall patterns and more frequent extreme weather events. It is projected that a 1.1 degrees Celsius increase in average temperature in Mindanao may occur, potentially causing the yield of key crops to decrease significantly. The World Bank estimates that the economic damages from climate change in the Philippines could reach up to 7.6 percent of gross domestic product by 2030 and 13.6% by 2040. Agriculture is responsible for 23 percent of the nation's greenhouse gas emissions, primarily through methane from rice cultivation and nitrous oxide from fertilizer use. The government is pursuing climate adaptation through a multiprong

articles.title: Has climate change brought mosquitoes to Iceland?
articles.summary: Iceland is no longer among the few places in the world free of mosquitoes. Scientists point to rising temperatures as the reason for the increase in the number of mosquitoes in the country.   ¬†  √Ç   y   i   a

articles.title: Punjab CM urges Centre to relax paddy procurement norms amid flood damage
articles.author: Nh Digital
articles.summary: Bhagwant Mann wants the Centre to relax the uniform specifications for crop procurement to support affected farmers. He has already written to the Centre seeking financial and logistical assistance for the farming community. Preliminary reports indicate extensive damage to paddy across several flood-affected districts.

articles.title: UN chief warns: Overshooting 1.5C climate target inevitable
articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres warns that efforts to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels would fail in the short term. The UN secretary-general urges countries to submit 'bold' climate plans that align with the Paris climate accords. He insists on the need to fight climate change disinformation.

articles.title: Despite Trump's words, China and others set higher climate goals
articles.author: Shannon Gibson
articles.summary: Marshall Islands is at risk of sea level rise due to climate change. The world is still not on track to stop rising global temperatures. China is the world's largest greenhouse gas emitter. The EU has made waves by extending its carbon pricing rules beyond its borders. Australia is aiming for net-zero emissions by 2050.

articles.title: Australians protect migrating red crabs
articles.author: Parks Australia Via Ap
articles.summary: Tens of millions of red crabs are making their way to the ocean as part of their annual migration on Christmas Island. A much smaller human population uses leaf blowers and garden rakes to help them on their way. Up to 200 million of the endemic crabs are on the tiny Australian island territory in the Indian Ocean.

articles.title: Has climate change brought mosquitoes to Iceland?
articles.summary: Iceland is no longer among the few places in the world free of mosquitoes. Scientists point to rising temperatures as the reason for the increase in the number of mosquitoes in the country.   ¬†  √Ç   y   i   a

articles.title: Caspian Sea Water Levels Drop to Record Lows Amid Natural Climate Shifts
articles.author: Margarita Kicherova
articles.summary: The Caspian Sea is shrinking due to climate change, reduced rainfall, and decreased river inflow. Ecologists warn that consequences are inevitable, but say there is no point in panicking or trying to 'save' the sea. The sea level fluctuates by several meters within a single generation. Coastal cities will have to adapt to the changing climate.

articles.title: Christmas Island crabs begin their epic migration to the ocean
articles.summary: Tens of millions of red crabs have begun their annual migration across Christmas Island, near Australia. Around 50 million red crabs travel from their homes in the island forests to the ocean to lay their eggs. Each female crab can produce up to 100,000 eggs. Once they've mated, the female crabs stay in little burrows on the beach for a few weeks. When the tide is high, they head into the water just before dawn to lay the eggs.

articles.title: Marine heatwave over Pacific Ocean could lead to flooding in north-west
articles.author: Eric Berger
articles.summary: A marine heatwave known as a blob was especially severe this year in the north-western and central Pacific Ocean. It could lead to increased flooding in the US Pacific north-west and especially wintery weather in eastern North America. The temperature in August in the northern Pacific was 2.5C above preindustrial levels, according to Berkeley Earth.

articles.title: Harmful Heat: Climate Change's Impact on Crop Yields and Quality in Japan
articles.author: Hirota Tomoyoshi
articles.summary: Temperatures in Japan are rising due to climate change. This has negative consequences for the nation's agriculture. The quality of rice, wheat, potatoes, and sugar beet is affected by high temperatures and prolonged rainfall. High temperatures cause sunburn in tomatoes and eggplants, and poor pollination in vegetables.

articles.title: F-35s, fires and fixing: Ukraine, Gaza wars threaten climate
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: The conflict in Ukraine has created vast amounts of planet-warming emissions. The first three years of conflict have generated almost 237 million metric tons of greenhouse gases. The cost of the climate damage attributable to the war is estimated to be $43 billion. The destruction of energy infrastructure in both Ukraine and Gaza has also increased emissions.

articles.title: F-35s, fires and fixing: Ukraine, Gaza wars threaten climate
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: The conflict in Ukraine has created vast amounts of planet-warming emissions. The first three years of conflict have generated almost 237 million metric tons of greenhouse gases. The cost of the climate damage attributable to the war is estimated to be $43 billion. The destruction of energy infrastructure in both Ukraine and Gaza has also increased emissions.

articles.title: What Americans think about the environmental impact of AI, according to a new poll
articles.author: Wtop
articles.summary: U.S. is building data centers for the development of artificial intelligence. Many Americans are concerned about the environmental impact of the data centers. Worries about how AI will affect the environment surpass concerns about other industries that worsen climate change, according to a new report.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Melissa lumbers through the Caribbean, killing an elderly man in Haiti
articles.author: D√°nica Coto
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Melissa is lumbering through the Caribbean Sea. It is bringing a risk of landslides and life-threatening flooding to Jamaica and the southern part of the island shared by the Dominican Republic and Haiti. It's expected to make landfall in the next few days.

articles.title: What Africans Want from COP30
articles.author: Carlos Lopes
articles.summary: COP30 is taking place in the Amazon. Developing economies must plan and propel the green transition. Africa's climate narrative has been one of victimhood. Africa contributes less than 4% of global greenhouse-gas emissions, but it is highly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. African countries face the world's highest borrowing costs. Africa needs an integrated carbon market.

articles.title: Japan's Endless Summer: Record Heat Reshapes The Nation's Seasons
articles.summary: The summer of 2025 has been the hottest ever recorded in Japan. It is the third consecutive year of record-breaking temperatures. The number of days with temperatures above 40¬∞C soared to 30, nearly double the previous record of 17 days set in 2018. The scorching summer has been linked to global warming and unusually high sea surface temperatures in both the Pacific Ocean and Sea of Japan. The unrelenting heat has taken a toll on Japan's agriculture and fisheries.

articles.title: As heat gets more extreme, pregnant farmworkers are increasingly at risk
articles.author: Cadillac News
articles.summary: Agricultural workers are among the most vulnerable to extreme heat. For pregnant workers, the risks are higher because the body must cool down to avoid heat exhaustion.    for pregnant agricultural workers. For them, the risk is higher because of the heat exposure.

articles.title: NHRC Urges States, UTs to Take Measures to Protect Homeless from Cold Waves
articles.author: M Srinivas
articles.summary: The National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) has urged 19 States and four UTs to take preemptive steps to protect vulnerable segments from the cold wave. The commission has reiterated the National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) guidelines to mitigate the impacts of cold waves.

articles.title: Experts issue warning on looming threat that could cause $150 billion economic hit: 'These events affect lives and livelihoods'
articles.author: Samantha Hindman
articles.summary: Experts issue warning on looming threat that could cause $150 billion economic hit. Extreme weather disrupts entire economic systems alongside property and land. Malta alone is expected to lose nearly 3% of its economic output by 2029. In the U.S., the Climate Action Tracker recently downgraded the nation's climate efforts from "insufficient" to "critically insufficient."

articles.title: Guterres Urges Climate Action and Warns Against Misinformation
articles.author: Naveen
articles.summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres calls for urgent global action on climate change, warns against misinformation and pushes for early-warning systems by 2027. He also urges countries to fight against "mis- and disinformation, online harassment, and greenwashing" in his address at an event on Early Warnings for All during the Extraordinary Session of the World Meteorological Congress in Geneva.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Melissa UPDATE: 9 provinces on Red Alert
articles.author: Merit Designs Consulting Group
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Melissa has maximum sustained winds of 85 km/h and is forecast to gradually strengthen in the coming days. 8 provinces and the National District have been placed on red alert. 13 provinces have been increased to yellow alert. 3 provinces are on green alert. Operators of small and medium-sized vessels along the Atlantic and Caribbean coasts are advised to remain in port.

articles.title: Valle Crucis Park After Helene
articles.author: Bob Griffin Local contributor
articles.summary: Six to seven feet of water flooded the Valle Crucis Community Park during Hurricane Helene last year. Thankfully, no one lives there and no one died. The VCCP was not purchased with government money. It is a user-supported, non-profit park located next to the Mast General Outlet store.

articles.title: This year, the last glimpse of the sun was on October 13, with its return not until February 27. Image: Pexels
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: Alert is the northernmost permanently inhabited place on Earth. It is located in the Canadian Arctic. It's in the north-west of the Arctic Circle, north of Alert, Canada. It lies in the Arctic Ocean.   ¬†   in the North Pole.

articles.title: Climate experts in Switzerland: 1.5 degree target is out of reach
articles.author: Swissinfo
articles.summary: Ten years after Paris Agreement, climate scientists in Switzerland no longer expect the world to limit warming to 1.5¬∞C. On average, they expect warming of 2.5 ¬∞C by 2100. More than 80 researchers in Switzerland took part in Swissinfo's survey.

articles.title: As heat gets more extreme, pregnant farmworkers are increasingly at risk
articles.author: Dorany Pineda
articles.summary: Agricultural workers are among the most vulnerable to extreme heat. Pregnant workers are coming under greater risk as temperatures rise because of climate change. Many of them are low-income Latino immigrants who toil under the sizzling sun or in humid nurseries open year round.

articles.title: FG validates national adaptation plan on climate change
articles.author: Oluyemi Ogunseyin
articles.summary: The Federal Government has validated the National Adaptation Plan on Climate Change in preparation for submission to the UNFCCC at the COP 30 in Belem, Brazil next month. Balarabe Lawal, Nigeria's Minister of Environment, said climate change is the defining issue of our time and Nigeria is highly vulnerable to its impacts.

articles.title: Christmas Island turns red as millions of crabs begin annual migration: Watch
articles.author: The News Digital
articles.summary: Tens of millions of crabs have started their annual migration odyssey on Christmas Island. The island is located off mainland Australia. Every summer, crabs emerge from their forest shelters and travel to the ocean to lay eggs and breed. The residents of the Island help these crabs to get to their destination safely by using garden rakes and leaf blowers.

articles.title: Shutdown threatens SNAP benefits (Oct. 23, 2025)
articles.author: Michael Hagerty
articles.summary: There is a possibility that SNAP benefits could stop in November. Brian Greene, CEO of Houston Food Bank, talks about how his organization is bracing for a surge in need. Amanda Leland, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund, discusses Sea Change at Brazos Bookstore on Thursday evening. There is an update on the health of Buffalo Bayou.

articles.title: Global warming pushing planet to the brink: UN Chief
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres warns that global warming is pushing the planet to the brink. He urges countries to implement disaster warning systems to protect people against extreme weather. The last ten years have been the hottest in history. Ocean heat is breaking records while decimating ecosystems.

articles.title: Atmospheric Absorption of Electromagnetic Radiation Adds to Rising Heat in Java
articles.author: Irsyan Hasyim
articles.summary: Sonni Setiawan is a lecturer at IPB University's Geophysics and Meteorology Department. His theory about the recent heatwaves affecting various regions in Indonesia is related to the absorption of electromagnetic field radiation by the atmosphere. According to Sonni, two main factors can trigger air heating in the lower atmospheric layer: the increase in the concentration of longwave radiation-absorbing gases and the change in land cover.

articles.title: The problem of climate change denialism and vested interests
articles.summary: There are sound scientific reasons to believe that human activity is playing a part in climate change. Many people are in denial about these questions, and their denialism is deep-seated. Donald Trump and fossil-fuel lobbyists are invested in the way things have been done in recent times. Some deniers have a vested interest in the processes that produce warming, and some speak from an inbuilt prejudice against science.

articles.title: Climate change and security: Potential instabilities in Bangladesh
articles.author: Prothom Alo English Desk Dhaka
articles.summary: Bangladesh Institute of Peace and Security Studies organised a workshop under the European Union-funded project 'Climate Change & Security: Potential Instabilities in Bangladesh'. The workshop, 'Water Insecurity and Climate-Induced Displacement in Bangladesh: Security Challenges and Policy Responses,' was held on 21 October 2025 at Hotel Renaissance, Dhaka. The event brought together distinguished policymakers, members of the security sector, researchers, academicians and young professionals to discuss one of the most pressing non-traditional security challenges confronting Bangladesh today.

articles.title: $250M hospital proposed for North Carolina's fastest-growing area
articles.author: Zac Ezzone
articles.summary: Coastal North Carolina is on the coast of North Carolina. It's called Coastal North Carolina, which means "coastal region". It's also known as "North Carolina-N.C." or "North-Capexical North Carolina".

articles.title: Concerns Rise over Ai's Environmental Impact Amid Rapid Data Center Expansion
articles.author: U.S. News
articles.summary: Concerns rise over Ai's environmental impact amid rapid data center expansion. Ai is expanding its data center facility.    for the data center's expansion is a concern for Ai's environment and environment of Ai's users, as well as Ai's future development.

articles.title: Pushing Human Boundaries: Exploring the Extremes of the Body's Capabilities
articles.author: Omar El Sayed
articles.summary: Unprecedented spring heatwave is affecting Australia, shattering historical temperature records across multiple states and territories. Western Sydney reached 37 degrees Celsius on Wednesday. The intense heat poses significant risks to public health, especially for vulnerable populations. Age (75+), low income, chronic illnesses and lack of access to air conditioning are some of the risk factors.

articles.title: MEDIA: THE AI STORM DROWNING PAKISTAN
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: The climate crisis in Pakistan has become the new norm, with floods impacting cities, livelihoods and homes of millions of people in the country. In 2025 alone, Pakistan experienced 25 million cases of floods, according to the UNFCCC report. The UNFCCC report predicts that in 2025 there will be 100 million floods in Pakistan.

articles.title: War's Carbon Footprint: Russia and Israel-Hamas Conflict Amplify Global Emissions
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Ukraine conflict has emitted nearly 237 million metric tons of greenhouse gases. The financial toll for climate damage already surpasses $43 billion. Lennard de Klerk, the study's lead author, emphasized the urgent need to address these rising emissions during a pivotal period for climate action.

articles.title: BBC Claim Indian Monsoons Failing, Data Shows Exact Opposite
articles.author: Principia Scientific
articles.summary: The facts don't matter to the BBC when it comes to 'climate change' and it's not important to them that they're wrong. It doesn't matter if they're right or wrong, it just matters to them.   √Ç. √Ç

articles.title: When twin volcanoes shook the world: How a 15th-century double eruption rewrote climate history
articles.author: Tags
articles.summary: In the late 1450s, Earth's climate was violently reshaped by forces far beyond human control. Two volcanoes erupted simultaneously in the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. Globalist institutions like the UN and WEF exploit this fact to push centralized control over energy, food, and human behavior.

articles.title: Heavy Rainfall Advisory
articles.author: WILLIAM WANYOIKE
articles.summary: Kenya Meteorological Department issues heavy rainfall advisory covering October 23 to 30, 2025. Affected areas include Lake Victoria Basin, Rift Valley, Highlands, both east and west of the Rift (including Nairobi), South-Eastern Lowlands, and parts of North-Eastern Kenya.

articles.title: When do the clocks go back?
articles.summary: The clocks in the UK are going back an hour on the last Sunday of October. This year the clocks will change from British Summer Time (BST) to Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) on Sunday 26 October. Most smart phones, computers and other digital devices connected to the internet update the time automatically, so you don't need to change the time on them. If you have a clock or watch that isn't connected with the internet, you have to change it yourself.

articles.title: Iceland's Unexpected Guest: The Arrival of Mosquitoes
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Iceland has recorded its first sighting of mosquitoes. The species is Culiseta annulata, which is typically found in northern Europe. The arrival of these cold-tolerant insects raises the question of whether they can establish a breeding population in the newly warmer conditions influenced by climate change.

articles.title: Once-rare Arctic extremes are now normal
articles.author: Chelsea Harvey
articles.summary: There are more extreme weather events in the Arctic than ever before, according to a new review of Arctic science published in Nature Reviews Earth & Environment. The study examined decades of research on the Arctic's temperatures, precipitation patterns, ocean heat and sea ice cover, as well as the vast Greenland ice sheet.

articles.title: New York air pollution is bad. Climate change made it worse.
articles.author: Ariel Wittenberg
articles.summary: 90% of organic aerosols in the air over Long Island, New York in 2023 were sensitive to global changes like extreme heat and wildfire smoke. Extreme weather events driven by climate change can exacerbate urban air pollution and threaten people's health, according to new research.

articles.title: Letter: No disputing the science around climate change
articles.author: Radley Kanda
articles.summary: The Star-Advertiser continues to print pieces that dispute the science around climate change. The argument that Hawaii is small and therefore has no obligation to address climate change is selfish. For the sake of our children, we need to change our behavior and work for the greater good.

articles.title: Depression over Arabian Sea located 1690km south of Karachi
articles.summary: The depression over southeast Arabian Sea moved slowly in north-northeast direction during past 24 hours. The center is monitoring the system and will keep the relevant quarters abreast. The depression is located near latitude 8.6¬∞N and longitude 67¬∞E about 1,800 km southeast of Karachi.

articles.title: Overshooting the critical 1.5¬∞C warming threshold is now INEVITABLE, UN chief warns - and the consequences are going to be 'devastating'
articles.author: JONATHAN CHADWICK
articles.summary: Ant√≥nio Guterres is the Secretary-General of the United Nations. He warned that the Paris Agreement to limit global warming to 1.5¬∞C above pre-industrial levels is unlikely to be implemented. The last 10 years have been the hottest in recorded history. The UN chief thinks Earth will warm by 3¬∞C (5.4¬∞F) by the end of the century.

articles.title: Lake Monger Primary School: Fears as parents may be forced to front the bill on planned Indigenous name change
articles.summary: Lake Monger Primary School in West Australia is planning to change its name to Lake Monger. Parents fear they may be forced to front the bill for the name change because of the cost of the new name.    .  √Ç  ¬†

articles.title: Warmer Nordic Springs Double Incidence Of Avian Malaria
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Rising spring temperatures have doubled the incidence of avian malaria in southern Sweden. Researchers from Lund University in Sweden collected samples every year from hundreds of blue tits in a single population at a local breeding area outside Lund. In the mid-1990s about 45% of all the birds carried an infection, but in recent years the annual incidence has risen to between 85 and 90%.

articles.title: Antigua Joins CARICOM in Call for Urgent Climate Action Ahead of COP30
articles.author: Editor
articles.summary: Antigua and Barbuda has joined CARICOM in adopting a declaration demanding greater global ambition and climate justice ahead of COP30 in Brazil. The declaration is on the tenth anniversary of the Paris Agreement and COP30. It urges major emitters to 'realign their 2035 targets with the 1.5¬∞C pathway and ramp up current climate actions.

articles.title: Mass migration of red crabs begins on Christmas Island, turning landscapes red
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: Tens of millions of red land crabs have started their yearly migration on Christmas Island, a remote Australian territory in the Indian Ocean near the Indonesian island of Java. The movement transforms roads, forest floors and low vegetation into a sweeping red procession as the crabs travel toward the coast to breed. Conservation authorities estimate around 50 million individuals participate when conditions are right. The migration is an iconic natural spectacle that attracts attention internationally.

articles.title: New low-pressure to form in Bay of Bengal tomorrow
articles.author: NT Bureau
articles.summary: A new low-pressure system is expected to form in the southeast Bay of Bengal tomorrow. The previous system had weakened before making an impact on the landmass. Tamil Nadu has activated its cyclone preparedness plans to mitigate potential impacts. District administrations have readied relief camps and coordinated rescue operations.

articles.title: Advisory issued for strong winds and rough seas
articles.author: Supuni Kulasinghe
articles.summary: The Department of Meteorology has issued a warning to multi-day fishing boats operating in the Bay of Bengal and Arabian Sea to remain cautious due to a developing weather system. The depression over the southeast Arabian Sea has been moving slowly north-northeastwards at a speed of around 3 kmph over the past six hours. It is expected to move northeastwards across the Arabian Sea during the next 24 hours.

articles.title: Watch: Millions of red crabs begin annual migration on Christmas Island
articles.author: Christmas Island
articles.summary: Millions of red crabs are migrating to the beach on Christmas Island every summer to lay eggs.   ¬†The island off mainland Australia experiences the event every summer. Watch the migration on 23 October 2025 here. It starts at 23:23 on Christmas island.

articles.title: Pursuing Net Zero Makes the UK Vulnerable to Bad Weather, BBC, Not Climate Change
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: BBC claims that the UK needs to prepare for increasing extreme weather as the planet is warming. This is false in its framing. The UK contributes very little carbon dioxide to the atmosphere and its emissions contribute only 0.88% to global warming. Data do not show that weather is becoming more extreme in the UK.

articles.title: Climate experts in Switzerland: 1.5 degree target is out of reach
articles.author: Kristian Foss Brandt
articles.summary: More than 80 researchers in Switzerland took part in Swissinfo's survey about climate research and the state of the climate. 95% do not believe it is realistic that the planet will meet the Paris Agreement's ideal target of limiting global warming to 1.5¬∞C. The scientists' scepticism comes as global temperatures continue to break records. Switzerland is warming twice as fast as the global average and could experience an increase of 4-4¬∞C locally by the end of this century.

articles.title: Mercury soars to blistering temperatures in Queensland
articles.summary: A hot mass is encompassing large parts of Queensland. There are extreme heatwave and fire danger alerts in the area. It is causing a suffocating heatwave in some parts of the state. It's also causing a fire danger alert in other parts.

articles.title: CM Chandrababu orders vigilant amid heavy rains in Andhra Pradesh
articles.author: The Hans India
articles.summary: Andhra Pradesh is experiencing heavy rainfall due to a severe low-pressure area forming over the Bay of Bengal. Chief Minister Chandrababu Naidu has been in constant communication with officials regarding the situation in the state. He has ordered the evacuation of residents in low-lying areas and the fortification of canals and ponds to prevent collapses.

articles.title: Wildlife will pay the price for our population explosion
articles.author: Portland Press Herald
articles.summary: Jane Goodall and David Attenborough warned of dire consequences for wildlife, their habitats and us if we don't find ways to cork the population-growth genie. CNN, NPR and PBS didn't mention their many statements. It may be significant that most such warnings come from them.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Melissa takes aim at Caribbean, islands on alert
articles.author: Al Jazeera
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Melissa is threatening the Caribbean Sea islands with dangerous landslides and life-threatening flooding. Officials urge residents of flood-prone areas to seek higher ground and shelter. Jamaica's eastern region could see significant rainfall, which is the main thing to be mindful of.

articles.title: People use garden tools to protect millions of migrating red crabs on Christmas Island
articles.summary: Tens of millions of red crabs are making their way to the ocean as part of their annual migration on Christmas Island. A much smaller human population uses leaf blowers and garden rakes to help them on their way. Up to 200 million of the endemic crabs are on the tiny Australian island territory in the Indian Ocean.

articles.title: China Emits Australia's Annual Carbon Output Every 12 Days, New Research Finds
articles.author: Rex Widerstrom
articles.summary: Australia's efforts to reduce carbon emissions are being negated by China. China emits as much carbon in 12 days as Australia does in an entire year, according to Institute of Public Affairs research. Cian Hussey, a research fellow at the Institute, says continuing to pursue a goal of Net Zero amounts to 'an act of devastating economic self-harm'

articles.title: Westpac ruling shows workplace flexibility pendulum has swung too far
articles.author: Jacinta Allan
articles.summary: Karlene Chandler moved to live closer to a private school for her children and wants to work remotely, which flouts Westpac's two-day-a-week return to office policy. The Fair Work Commission has ordered Westpac to grant her request.

articles.title: Magpies are being struck down by a mystery paralysis. It could be a canary in the coal mine
articles.author: Bronte Gossling
articles.summary: Some magpies in Perth and south Western Australia are suffering from a rare neurological condition called magpie paralysis syndrome. The number of birds in hospital has increased dramatically in the last 12 months. The cause of the syndrome is unknown. An update from Murdoch University is expected in the coming weeks.

articles.title: Magpies are being struck down by a mystery paralysis. It could be a canary in the coal mine
articles.author: Bronte Gossling
articles.summary: There is a huge increase in the number of magpies being admitted to WA Wildlife Hospital with a neurological condition called magpie paralysis syndrome. The condition is similar to black and white syndrome, which affects birds including currows, crows, ravens, birds of prey, and magpie. The cause of the syndrome is unknown, but the symptoms are similar.

articles.title: Andhra Pradesh On Red Alert As Heavy Rains Lash Several Districts
articles.author: ETV Bharat
articles.summary: A red alert has been issued in Andhra Pradesh due to heavy rains. There is a risk of flash floods in Guntur, Prakasam, Nellore, Chittoor, Kurnool, and Yanam districts. Floodwaters have overflowed at Chapta in Kammavaripalle of Ananthasagaram mandal, prompting authorities to declare a holiday in the educational institutions for the second day.

articles.title: Gujarat weather: Unseasonal rain, strong winds hit Valsad, more showers likely after October 25
articles.author: Gujarat Samachar
articles.summary: Unseasonal rain and gusty winds hit parts of south Gujarat's Valsad district during Diwali and New Year festivities. IMD has warned of thunderstorms with lightning and winds gusting at 30 kmph in several coastal belts over the next five days. Tamil Nadu is bracing for heavy rain.

articles.title: State insurance commissioner visits OBX to survey sites of recent home collapses
articles.author: Pre News
articles.summary: Mike Causey visited Buxton, North Carolina this week. He was shocked to see the number of oceanfront homes that have collapsed into the Atlantic Ocean and the ones on the brink of collapse. Causey has urged North Carolina's Congressional delegation to look into remedies for the threatened structures.

articles.title: APTOPIX Australia Extreme Weather
articles.author: Ï∞®Ìä∏ÌÜµÏó≠ÏÇ¨ Vip
articles.summary: Temperatures soared close to 40 degrees Celsius (104 degrees Fahrenheit) in some of the hottest temperatures recorded for October in the Sydney region on Wednesday, Oct. 22, 2025, as temperatures soared to 40 degree Celsius in Port Stephens, north of Sydney.

articles.title: Climate Change: $150 billion a year needed to safeguard South Asia food production: Report
articles.author: DHNS
articles.summary: The research was conducted by Climate Focus for the Family Farmers for Climate Action, a new global alliance representing 95 million small-scale producers across Africa, Latin America, Asia and the Pacific. It was done for the new Global Alliance for Family Farmers For Climate Action.

articles.title: El Ni√±o Intensifies, Causing Climate Whiplash
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The El Ni√±o‚ÄìSouthern Oscillation (ENSO) is projected to undergo a dramatic transformation due to greenhouse warming. The study projects an abrupt shift within the next 30-40 years from irregular to highly regular ENSO cycles. This synchronization will lead to stronger rainfall fluctuations in Southern California and the Iberian Peninsula.

articles.title: How climate change is driving migrants from their homes to NYC
articles.author: Carla Mandiola
articles.summary: Gricelda left Guatemala in 2018. Mohamed left Senegal in 2023. Hossain couldn't pay the hospital bill to bring his wife and newborn daughter home in 2022. His savings were gutted after a decade of frequent flooding that destroyed harvests in Feni, Bangladesh.

articles.title: Alert issued as low pressure system brings heavy rain to Andhra Pradesh
articles.author: Pavan Bandari
articles.summary: A low pressure area in the southwest Bay of Bengal is expected to weaken gradually and transform into a low-pressure zone within the next 12 hours. A surface circulation along the Andaman Sea coast intensifies the likelihood of heavy rains across Andhra Pradesh over the next 24 hours. The Meteorological Department has issued a red alert statewide, warning of flash floods in Guntur, Prakasam, Nellore, Chittoor, and Kurnool districts.

articles.title: Wildfires have consumed vast chunks of Ukraine. Is Russia deliberately fuelling the flames?
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: In 2024, nearly a million hectares of Ukraine's land burned due to heat, mines and shelling. Drone strikes on firefighters raised the question of war crimes in Ukraine, as seen in the video.   ¬†  √Ç   in 2024.

articles.title: Expect heavy in most parts of Kenya
articles.author: JANET ONYANGO
articles.summary: The Kenya Meteorological Department has issued a heavy rainfall advisory, warning that intense downpours are expected across several parts of the country between October 23 and October 30, 2025. Rainfall is expected to intensify to more than 30mm within 24 hours and spread to the Highlands East of the Rift Valley, including Nairobi, and Southeastern Lowlands from Thursday, October 23, 2025, and will continue to extend to the Northeast from October 30.

articles.title: Indian-Origin Historian Sunil Amrith Wins British Academy Book Prize
articles.author: Jinit Parmar
articles.summary: Sunil Amrith won the 2025 British Academy Book Prize for his book The Burning Earth: An Environmental History of the Last 500 years. He was born in Kenya to South Indian parents and educated at Cambridge. He is now a Professor of History at Yale University.

articles.title: Jamaica joins regional effort to support women in climate projects
articles.summary: Jamaica is among eight Caribbean countries to join a Gender Smart Facility led by the Caribbean Biodiversity Fund (CBF) and Global Affairs Canada to transform how climate finance reaches women and vulnerable communities. The initiative embeds gender analysis at every stage of project development. The facility was launched through CBF's Caribbean Organisations for a Resilient Environment project.

articles.title: Disaster choppers prepared for looming bushfire season
articles.author: Grace Crivellaro
articles.summary: Australia's firefighting aircraft fleet is prepared to respond to bushfires and hazardous weather as temperatures rise ahead of the summer. The fleet is made up of a fleet of firefighting planes.    for the emergency situations such as bushfires or hazardous weather.

articles.title: NHS could save ¬£54m a year if Britons stop doing this one thing
articles.author: Alice Lilley
articles.summary: The NHS could save ¬£54 million if non-essential wood burning was stopped. Thousands of deaths could also be prevented if Britons stopped heating their home using a wood burner or open fire. An open fire or wood burning stove is the most polluting way to heat a home, according to Global Action Plan.

articles.title: SM City La Union Boosts Climate Resilience with Rainwater Catchment System (SM Prime Holdings Inc)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Climate change is driving heavier rains and more frequent floods in the Philippines. Proactive flood prevention is a key part of building resilient communities in the country, according to the World Resources Institute (WRI). WRI is based in San Fernando, La Union, Philippines.

articles.title: Weather In Words: Fancying fall's first chill
articles.summary: David and Ryan stroll through Dothan to ask if others are enjoying the sudden chill. The temperature is between the 70s and 40s.   ¬†   in Dothans.  in the last few days it's been in the mid-70s and now it's in the 40s and it's sunny.

articles.title: Nature reforms all at sea as Libs, Greens play hardball
articles.author: Zac de Silva
articles.summary: A major overhaul of Australia's environment laws has a rocky road ahead as it faces fierce criticism from the coalition and the Greens, who are critical of the proposed law changes. The bill is expected to be voted on in the next few months.    for approval.

articles.title: AGRA, Ministry of Agriculture validate Uganda's climate vulnerability maps in push for stronger climate resilience
articles.author: Nelson Mandela
articles.summary: The Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA) and Uganda's Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Industry and Fisheries held a Policy and Community Engagement Workshop on Climate Vulnerability and Resilience from October 22-23 in Entebbe. The event brought together government leaders, researchers, private sector actors, farmers, youth, and women groups to discuss the realities of climate change, the risks facing Uganda's food systems, and the policies needed to build resilience in the agriculture sector. The workshop concluded with the validation of Uganda's first climate vulnerability maps.

articles.title: Backtracking on climate action would be 'utter madness', minister tells Yorkshire Post summit
articles.author: Chris Burn
articles.summary: Katie White is the Government Minister for Climate Change and a Labour MP for Leeds North West. She spoke at the Yorkshire Post Climate Change Summit at the Leeds Conservatoire. She has previously been awarded an MBE for her successful campaigning for the introduction of the Climate Change Act 2008.

articles.title: Surfer in distress and rescuer both die in stormy weather in Australia
articles.summary: People walk on Frankston Pier in Melbourne, Australia, on Thursday, Oct. 23, 2025. New for subscribers! Gift this article to your friends and family for free. flag wire: true flag sponsored: false article_type: pubinfo.section: cms.site.custom.site, website: therecord.com sWebsitePrimaryPublication: publications/waterloo_region_record bHasMigrated.avatar: false first author: first author.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Melissa lumbers through the Caribbean as islands take cover from rain
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Melissa is moving through the Caribbean. It poses risks of landslides and life-threatening flooding to Jamaica and southern Hispaniola. The eastern region may receive up to 12 inches of rain. There is an increasing likelihood that Melissa will develop into a large and dangerous hurricane.

articles.title: Funding the Future We Want (WHO - World Health Organization Regional Office for The Western Pacific)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: In 2024, the Department of Health recorded 34 cases and six deaths from heat-related illnesses. Rising temperatures and extreme weather threaten lives and health systems in the Philippines due to climate change, according to the DOH's report. The report also mentions that climate change is affecting the health of Filipinos.

articles.title: Antarctica's September weather driving current hot windy conditions
articles.author: Alexa Cook of
articles.summary: Hastings and Havelock North are expected to hit 29C today. There is a total fire ban for Hawke's Bay District until October 27. Three fires are burning in Porangahau, one is 250ha in size and hasn't been contained yet because high winds have grounded helicopters.

articles.title: Rare Ground Parrot Resurfaces in Jervis Bay, Australia: A Snapshot on Facebook
articles.author: Omar El Sayed
articles.summary: The Ground Parrot (Pezoporus wallicus) is one of Australia's most enigmatic and threatened birds. Its population is estimated to be between 250 and 800 individuals. Its main threats are habitat loss, predation and wildfires. BirdLife Australia is engaged in conservation efforts to protect this species.

articles.title: Sunil Amrith's Masterpiece Wins British Academy Book Prize
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Sunil Amrith's book 'The Burning Earth: An Environmental History of the Last 500 years' has been awarded the British Academy Book Prize for its critical insights amid the ongoing climate crisis. The British Academy emphasizes the work's comprehensive research into how historical events like colonization and industrialization have influenced the climate.

articles.title: Antarctic weather behind NZ's hot, windy spell
articles.summary: Antarctica's warm weather in September is driving the gale-force winds and hot temperatures being felt across New Zealand this week. Temperatures could reach nearly 30C in Hawke's Bay on Thursday. The region is under a strong wind watch as fire crews work to try and contain a huge bush fire near Porangahau.

articles.title: ‚ÄòMust be stopped': Sydney faces ‚Äòannoying' moth infestation
articles.author: Eleanor Wicklund
articles.summary: The moths are back in Sydney. This year's warm spell has sent them flocking into homes, cars and even office desks earlier than usual. Entomologists say it's a good thing as it means there's food for baby birds hatching nearby. Pest2Kill director Julian Bracewell says prevention is always the best solution.

articles.title: Storm No. 12 weakens into tropical depression
articles.author: SGGPO
articles.summary: Tropical storm No. 12 has been downgraded to a tropical depression. It is moving inland across Central Vietnam, unleashing heavy rain, rough seas and flooding along coastal areas. The center of the tropical depression is located 80 km east-northeast of Da Nang City. The system is currently moving southwestward at 10‚Äì15 km per hour.

articles.title: Global warming is pushing planet to the brink, UN chief says
articles.author: Anwar Iqbal
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres warned that global warming is pushing the planet to the brink. He urged countries to implement disaster warning systems to protect people against extreme weather. The 2015 Paris climate accords aimed to limit global warming to well below 2C above pre-industrial levels and 1.5C if possible.

articles.title: Mosquitoes Found in Iceland for First Time as Temperatures Rise
articles.author: Colombia One
articles.summary: Iceland has confirmed its first wild mosquitoes for the first time on record. Climate shifts are warming the Arctic faster than ever before, according to AfroBrazilian and AfroBrasil's Wikipedia.   ¬†   .   for example.

articles.title: The groundbreaking breeding programme that's reducing methane in cow burps
articles.summary: Agriculture accounts for 10% of the UK's greenhouse gas emissions. The country's nine million cows and calves are a significant contributor to that figure.   √Ç  ¬†   in the UK, and in the U.S. as well.

articles.title: Hanoi and HCM City stuck in outdated flood models, experts warn
articles.author: Vietnamnet News
articles.summary: Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City's anti-flood systems can no longer keep pace with rapid urban growth and climate change. Experts call for adaptive, flexible approaches to prevent future flooding in the two cities.   √Ç. √Ç

articles.title: ‚ÄòClimate risks emerging as biggest threat to public health in Pakistan'
articles.author: M. Waqar Bhatti
articles.summary: Zulfiqar Bhutta warned that climate change is one of the biggest threats to public health in Pakistan. He spoke at the 1st Health Research Symposium organized by the Pakistan Islamic Medical Association at Jinnah Postgraduate Medical Centre on Tuesday. He stressed that Pakistan needs to treat climate adaptation as a public health emergency. Speakers highlighted that while Pakistan faces multiple health challenges, it also lacks a strong research culture.

articles.title: UH research: Climate whiplash effects due to rapidly intensifying El Ni√±o cycles
articles.summary: Changes in El Ni√±o-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) could reshape global rainfall patterns, according to a new study led by researchers at the University of Hawai'i at MƒÅnoa. The study projects an abrupt shift within the next 30 to 40 years from El Ni√±o and La Ni√±a cycles to highly regular oscillations.

articles.title: Climate Science, Early Warnings Crucial to Saving Lives
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Mr. Guterres launched the Early Warnings for All initiative aiming to ensure that "everyone, everywhere" is protected by an alert system by 2027. More than half of all countries are now equipped with multi-hazard early-warning systems. The world's least developed countries have nearly doubled their capacity since official reporting began, but there is still a long way to go.

articles.title: Study: Flood Risk Reduces AU$42 Billion From Australian Property Values
articles.summary: Homes in flood zones have lost $42.2 billion in value this year. A typical three-bedroom, two-bathroom home in a flood zone is worth $75,000 less. Chelmer and Graceville lost 10.6%, and the Brisbane-area dropped 8.7%.

articles.title: They Never Checked the Numbers
articles.author: Dear friend
articles.summary: The Australian government is reshaping the country based on climate change numbers it never bothered to check. The numbers form the foundation of the government's first policy. The Australian Climate Service (ACS) openly admitted before a Senate Estimates hearing that this is the case.

articles.title: Indian-Origin Historian Sunil Amrith Wins British Academy Book Prize
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: 'The Burning Earth: An Environmental History of the Last 500 years' by Indian-origin historian Sunil Amrith has been named the winner of this year's British Academy Book Prize. It is a prestigious award.   ¬†  √Ç

articles.title: China Emits Australia's Annual Carbon Output Every 12 Days, New Research Finds
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: Australia's efforts to reduce emissions are being negated by China. China emits as much carbon in 12 days as Australia does in an entire year, according to new research by the Institute of Public Research.   ¬†   .   in the report.

articles.title: GBCA backs NCC 2025 progress, urges continued climate focus (Green Building Council of Australia)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Green Building Council of Australia welcomes the finalisation of key reforms under the National Construction Code. GBCA backs NCC 2025 progress and urges continued focus on climate change.  (GBCA's News Media release is dated 22 October 2025, and is published by News Media of Australia.

articles.title: Expect heavy rainfall in most parts of Kenya
articles.author: JANET ONYANGO
articles.summary: The Kenya Meteorological Department has issued a heavy rainfall advisory, warning that intense downpours are expected across several parts of the country between October 23 and October 30, 2025. Rainfall is expected to intensify to more than 30mm within 24 hours and spread to the Highlands East of the Rift Valley, including Nairobi, and Southeastern Lowlands from Thursday, October 23, 2025, and will continue to extend to the Northeast from October 30.

articles.title: When twin volcanoes shook the world: How a 15th-century double eruption rewrote climate history
articles.author: Natural News
articles.summary: In the late 1450s, Earth‚Äôs climate was violently reshaped by forces far beyond human control. For centuries, historians and scientists have pointed out this fact. Today, scientists have a better understanding of the climate change.    .   ,

articles.title: Illinois Farms Lose $67.2M per Year to Natural Hazards
articles.author: Mount Carmel Register
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Lorenzo is weakening over open water, but additional waves remain under the surface despite the storm's weakening. The storm is no longer a tropical storm, but still has some waves under it's surface.   ¬†  √Ç

articles.title: Mongolia joins global campaign to celebrate snow leopard day
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Mongolia joined a global campaign to celebrate the snow leopard day. The campaign encouraged individuals, institutions and communities around the world to take part in the celebration.   ¬†  √Ç   i   in the campaign.  i.

articles.title: 3,639 died in cold waves: NHRC orders states to step up protection
articles.author: Madhyamam
articles.summary: There will be 3,639 deaths caused by cold waves between 2019 and 2023, according to the National Human Rights Commission. 19 state governments and 4 Union Territory administrations have been directed to take pre-emptive measures to protect vulnerable populations ahead of upcoming winter season.

articles.title: Traffic noise joins land clearance as damaging to bird survival
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: From agriculture and urban land clearance to loss of habitat and deforestation, there are many causes of habitat loss in the world of agriculture, urbanization, and deforestation.    .   For more information, go to: http://www.cnn.com/news/environmental-issues/

articles.title: Despite Trump's words, China and others set higher climate goals
articles.author: Asiatimes
articles.summary: In the Marshall Islands, people are aware of climate change. The land is only 7 feet above sea level. Storms more easily flood communities and farmland with saltwater. Warming ocean water is "greatest con job ever perpetuated", according to scientists.

articles.title: Farming in the fire: Climate change threatens PH breadbasket
articles.author: The Manila Times
articles.summary: Climate change is a global crisis. It threatens revenues, livelihoods and the fabric of rural communities in the Philippines. Without decisive action, it will be devastating for the nation's breadbasket and its agricultural sector. The Philippines is blessed with fertile lands and a hardworking agriculture sector.
